(UPDATE: after four years of use, I have found through experimentation with higher and lower settings, that keeping it on the middle &#x27;5&#x27; setting works best for me.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;To use, fill the tank with &#x27;lukewarm&#x27; water, according to the directions, and have at.  While moving the handpiece around your mouth, don&#x27;t twist the handpiece, instead turn the knob at the end that holds the waterjet attachment to keep it directed at your tooth-gum interface.  At the &#x27;5&#x27; setting the water seems to last maybe a minute or better, give-or-take (I haven&#x27;t timed it).  After using the Waterpik for a week now, this amount of time works out just fine, but when first starting out, I had to refill it one or two times.  Now, one tank fill is all I need because I&#x27;ve better learned how to use it properly.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Some mentioned that you&#x27;ll get wet, and if you don&#x27;t use a little care, you will.  Just remember this: water is going into your mouth; unless you plan to swallow all of it, then it&#x27;s gonna come back out, right?  Lean low over the sink when you use this Waterpik and you&#x27;ll be just fine.  Or, stand up straight, complain that the coiled tubing is too short, and let water run down your chest and arm.  When using this product, common sense is optional, but highly recommended.  Even lacking common sense, though, the Waterpik is probably harmless in most ways, but it is great fun to shoot water at the cats, my second-favorite use for this product.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I used to use a peroxide-based whitening rinse between flossing and brushing, so now instead of using it like mouthwash before brushing, I just add the same amount to the water as I fill the Waterpik tank, and it makes the cleaning experience even better.  However, remember that some plastic and internal components of the Waterpik are likely sensitive to certain chemicals, so if I add anything other than tap water, I rinse the tank out, and run one-half a tank of plain water through the system to rinse all chemicals out.  The manual states: \\&quot;...Note: use of some antibacterial solutions could shorten the life of your WaterpikÂ®\\&quot;Water Flosser.\\&quot;  Like I said.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Also (about once a month for me), to help keep the unit sanitized, I will fill the holding tank with a VERY dilute bleach solution, let it sit in the tank for 15 minutes, then turn on the unit and let it run into the sink until almost empty, then turn it off again and let it sit for another 15 minutes to disinfect the internal parts, coiled tubing, and water jet.  Then I rinse out the holding tank, refill it with plain tap water, and run it through the Waterpik to rinse it out good.  Disinfection is even more important if you use well water, or other non-chlorinated water supplies.  Doing this routine with white vinegar is also useful to remove biofilm buildup, which you will have anytime water is stagnant for an extended period of time (especially in warm weather and climates).  In other words, don&#x27;t let your Waterpik sit unused for extended periods of time.  Other reviews have mentioned having black mold forming inside the handpieces, and the truth is this black biofilm will form *anywhere* water is allowed to sit stagnant for too long (this will even happen with chlorinated city water, as the chlorine or chloramines will break down in a short period of time, leaving the water prone to bacterial buildup).  I&#x27;m very surprised that Water Pik, Inc. didn&#x27;t include any sanitizing information in the manual.  Where you have water, you will have bacteria, which loves water as much as we do.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Chlorine and chloramines added to tap water by the city will keep bacterial growth in check, as they are supposed to, but as they kill bacteria, it neutralizes (uses up) the chlorine/chloramines at the same time, so after a while there is no chlorine left; it is spent, leaving the water unguarded, and bacteria will then begin to colonize the water.  The speed with which this happens depends on several factors, and so varies.  It will be worse for some people, and places, than others.  That is why chlorinated water will only keep your Waterpik (or anything else that holds water) clear of most bacteria for only a little while.  Then you start getting the black &#x27;mold&#x27;, the biofilm buildup.  Just so you know.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;DO NOT, repeat, DO NOT leave the white lid sitting on top of the water holding tank, even when empty, even if you dry it out after use!  Placing the lid on the holding tank when not in use will speed the growth of bacteria!  Covering the water holding tank was only acceptable when the Waterpik was new, in the box, unused, and completely dry.  It is important that any residual water and/or moisture is able to evaporite to the atmosphere.  This is the only way to keep bacterial growth in check, as well as the occasional chemical disinfection, since it is IMPOSSIBLE to completely remove all water from the Waterpik after use.  If you *do* leave the lid on the water holding tank (I know, it does look better with it on), then plan to disinfect your machine more often.  When the water seems to have a bit of a funny taste to it, it&#x27;s usually time to disinfect.  Instead of using the lid, I drape a clean, dry, washcloth over the unit when not in use.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;CLEANING NOTE: As mentioned above, leaving water sitting in *anything* invites bacterial buildup, and the formation of biofilms.  Thus, it is important to empty as much water from inside your Waterpik as possible AFTER EACH USE (it&#x27;s less important if it is used every day, or several times a day).  For instance, after I finish each night&#x27;s use, I...&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;1) remove the water holding tank and shake out any residual water,&lt;br /&gt;2) then hold the handpiece down in the sink to allow as much water as possible to drain from inside the Waterpik and coiled tubing; when the water stops flowing,&lt;br /&gt;3) I remove the clear plastic wand (waterjet) from the handpiece, shake residual water out of the clear wand and handpiece, then place the handpiece back into its holder on the unit, and set the clear jet fitting in the depression at the top of the white Waterpik body where the water tank normally rests,&lt;br /&gt;4) then place the empty water reservoir, UPSIDE DOWN, resting on top of the Waterpik body at a 90 degree angle, so there is plenty of open space for air movement to dry everything out within a few hours.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Very dilute bleach with a dwell-time of 10 or 15 minutes, run through the entire system occasionally, is the best way (along with the steps listed above) to keep the Waterpik clean and disinfected.  Do this occasionally with white vinegar as well, as the vinegar will break up and remove any biofilm build up (any dilute acid would do this, but vinegar is cheap, readily available, and safe).  Keep in mind that although vinegar will remove biofilm build up, it is NOT a very good disinfectant; that is what bleach is for!  I find that by bleaching once a month, I have no biofilm build up, and therefore only vinegar my Waterpik maybe twice a year.  However, if you have hard water (most areas of the country), then vinegar treatments will be needed more often to remove mineral buildup (a dry, white-ish powder or stain).&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;For those who have not sanitized their Waterpiks, I would recommend using full-strength white vinegar first to remove biofilm.  If there is a lot coming out, I&#x27;d rinse out the Waterpik and repeat the vinegar procedure.  Once the vinegar comes out fairly clean, then rinse the system out again with a full tank of tap water, THEN do the dilute bleach procedure.  After that, bleaching every other week, or maybe once a month (it depends), will be sufficient to keep biofilm build up at bay, and then vinegar won&#x27;t be needed so often.  Also know that bleaching too often will degrade components of your Waterpik, so don&#x27;t bleach any more often than necessary.  Vinegar will probably not cause any damage to your Waterpik, unless left in for unreasonable periods of time.  Just run vinegar through, then rinse it out; you can let it dwell for awhile before rinsing, if you wish.  Quick and simple.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Also very important, *** NEVER MIX ANYTHING WITH BLEACH!***  Never try to do the bleaching and vinegar at the same time!  This is mixing an acid and a base; bad idea, as it will produce some very unhealthy fumes, and such a concoction will likely damage your Waterpik, you, and your cats.  Think of the cats!!  Always thoroughly rinse out the Waterpik after using anything other than water in it, such as bleach, vinegar, or mouthwashes.  This may seem like a lot of work but your teeth are worth it, and this will also help your Waterpik last longer.  If you bleach and vinegar your Waterpik on the same day, always do a fresh water rinse between the vinegar and bleach processes!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;BTW, if/when you bleach the unit, use very dilute bleach, as strong bleach, or dilute bleach left in the unit too long, will likely damage components of the Waterpik.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(And, just to be clear, never use the Waterpik in your mouth with bleach!  Common sense, I know, but I feel I should add that... and the vinegar probably wouldn&#x27;t taste very good either.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;About the unit itself: many other reviews mentioned the many accessories that come with this unit and how most of them are useless; I agree.  I use the &#x27;basic&#x27; waterjet fitting, the clear one, and that&#x27;s probably the only one I&#x27;ll ever use.  The others are more specialized, such as people who have braces, deep gum pockets, inexplicably dirty tongues, etc.  But I might try the toothbrush fitting someday.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Noise-wise, the Waterpik is a little loud, but I&#x27;ve never used any previous Waterpik units to compare it to, so all I can say is that I don&#x27;t find it excessively loud.  I put two dry, folded, washcloths under it to dampen the noise, and it helps (acoustic decoupling from the countertop, cabinet, and walls).&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;In conclusion, do yourself a huge favor and buy a Waterpik!  And *especially* if you have kids, buy one for them too!  I&#x27;ve even given these as gifts; I wish I&#x27;d known about them long ago.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;UPDATE: Before I used this Waterpik, my twice-annual teeth cleanings would take forever, and on a few occasions, lasted so long that I actually had to come back in a second time for the cleaning to be finished!  Now, my cleanings rarely last more than 15 minutes, and I am always complimented on how good my gums are and the very low plaque buildup.  Wohoo!  BTW, I have not flossed since buying this (except when traveling when I don&#x27;t have the Waterpik with me).  Many people still floss, but I hate flossing, and wondered how much good it would do to just use this Waterpik instead of flossing, and it seems to be working out great for me, two years later.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This has been used nightly, for a little over 2 years now, and still works like the day I bought it.  The only problem has been the button on the handle to temporarily stop the water flow sticks, but resets when I turn the Waterpik off, but I don&#x27;t consider this a major issue; I&#x27;d still buy this Waterpik again without pause, and I will when this one conks out on me.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;UPDATE Dec. 2013:  This Waterpik is still working great, used nightly.  One of the best products I&#x27;ve ever bought.  Still highly and strongly recommended.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;UPDATE Mar. 2014:  Still working great.  Money well spent!</li>

    <li> The Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser may not be perfect, but it is very good. It is probably the best water irrigator available.   I previously had used the Interplak irrigator (by Conair). The older round-reservoir version that I had purchased had trouble getting &amp;#34;primed&amp;#34;, so it would not pump water.  I called Conair customer service, and we worked with the unit (over the phone), and finally got it pumping.  Conair&#x27;s customer service was very good. No complaints.  After a few months&#x27; use, however, the Conair irrigator tip attachment I was using flew off the end of the flexi-tube.  The attached tip would no longer stay attached while under pressure. The tips stay in place with a simple pressure fit &amp;#34;click&amp;#34;. Apparently, there was fatigued plastic combined with perhaps a slightly too-small size of the attachment.  I called Conair for a set of replacement tips.  But, Conair (amazingly) said the tips were not available separately. They sent me an entirely new unit.  The new unit was the newer squared reservoir version.  The on/off knob on the new version was very small and difficult to turn without holding onto the unit with the other hand. The unit did not have rubber feet that would keep it from sliding away. So, to turn it on or off is a two-handed operation! This is very inconvenient, especially when you are holding the flosser wand in one hand. After a few months&#x27; use, the &amp;#34;pause&amp;#34; button on the flosser handle burst off, and water would spray out of the resulting opening. The pause button&#x27;s little plastic ear had broken off under pressure.  I could see that it was not repairable. I thought I could maybe swap out the entire flexi-tube assembly with the one from my older version. But, this is not possible due to some small design changes internally.  The parts are not interchangeable.  Now, the Waterpik:  Rather than try another Conair, I decided to try the Waterpik after looking at reviews online.  Some others had complained that the Waterpik was loud.  Believe me: the Waterpik is quiet compared with the Conair. It has a &amp;#34;dampened&amp;#34; buzz sound  (vs. a &amp;#34;buzzy&amp;#34; buzz sound). The on/off button is an easy rocker style switch that allows one-handed operation without having the unit slide away. The lid serves as a closed storage unit for the accessory tips (a convenience).  The tips are held in place with a mechanical locking mechanism -- much stronger than the pressure-fit technique of the Conair. The flexitube coils conveniently for storage into a storage compartment, and the coiling storage is much easier than for the Conair. The best feature of this unit is the handle design. The tips are inserted into a handle that has a knurled rotatable end. (The Conair does not have this.) You can turn the knurled knob with your fingers (which is holding your tip) and aim the tip in any direction you want. You do not have to rotate or contort your wrist to reach different teeth  -- just turn the knob to aim the jet stream where you want.  This is a simple but very major convenience.  The water pressure produced by the Waterpik is much higher than for the Conair. I use the highest setting at all times. Many people will think that the highest setting is uncomfortable, though.  UPDATE 2017: I&#x27;ve been very happy with the Waterpick flosser. But, BEWARE: it does wear out over time. It has a 3-yr warranty. I found that my Waterpik had noticebly-reduced pressure after about 4 years, maybe 5-years&#x27; of use. I&#x27;m sure its pressure decreased gradually over time, but I only noticed it recently. So, I ordered another identical Waterpik (Feb. 2017) and the new one, as I suspected, has a much more powerful water stream vs.my old one. I estimate that my old Waterpik was providing a water stream at a Level 4 or 5 on the brand new Waterpik. So, there was a major deterioration over time, and it was so gradual that I didn&#x27;t really pay attention to it.  My only suggestions for improving the product:  A bit longer (8&amp;#34;?) flexi-tube, and quiet it  down (if possible). But, the sound level is NOT terrible. It is simply what you might expect from a small pump.  All in all, the Waterpik is a reliable, fairly quiet,well-designed product. It is heavy enough to not slide toward you while you are using it or when you push the on/off rocker switch. [The newer model by Waterpik is apparently much lighter, and has the problem of sliding during use. So, it seems that the older model, reviewed here, is the better model.] It works well at cleaning food and plaque from teeth. It probably should be replaced after every 4-years of use if you want the more powerful water stream to be in effect.</li>

This last time I was determined to figure out once and for all what the exact source of the problem is, so I dissected the failed handle and sure enough immediately becomes apparent the design flow and why is bound to leak and fail. There is an O ring loosely encased in a small plastic chamber in the hose assembly the O ring with not much to keep it in place soon becomes misaligned and disengages the water tip causing a major leak. Since that part is sealed there is no way to service it therefore the entire hose assembly must be replaced. The question is why the company has not come up with a new engineered handle that takes care of this and rather keeps supplying the failed units with handles that they know will fail too.     <li> Okay, I would have given this 5 stars, but it failed after 4 months. A few days before the leak happened, the tip became noticeably harder to insert into the handle.  If you eject the tip and look down the insertion hole in the handle with a flashlight, you may see a warped black thing that looks out-of-place.  This is the rubber o-ring seal that has become dislodged from the slot that holds it in place.    FIX: Luckily I was able to fix it, for now at least.  Since it seems impossible to disassemble the handle without breaking it, you need to somehow slide the o-ring back into place.  This was a royal pain to do and took about an hour, though I hope to do it faster if it ever breaks again. If you&#x27;re interested, here&#x27;s what to do:  You&#x27;ll need to straighten out a paper clip, then put a tiny 90 degrees bend at the end, the smallest you can manage using say needle-nose pliers.  Assuming you don&#x27;t have 3 hands, you&#x27;ll need to position a flashlight (hands-free) so that it shines on the side of the handle near the top (say, around the eject button); if it&#x27;s bright enough at the right place, the light will penetrate the handle enough for you to see the interior when you look down the hole.  Insert the paper clip and try to nudge down or hook upwards the o-ring back into its indention.  If you hook it, you can pull it all the way out if you want, then push it back in.  Try to get one side of the o-ring to fall in, then pull the other side into place.  You&#x27;ll need to have an idea where the slot is first.  Use the paper clip to feel around for it.  It should be a little past the gate that holds the tip in place (the ejection button raises it).    This is harder than it looks, but now it&#x27;s back to working perfectly.  My guess is that every once in a while, an insertion or ejection of the tip accidentally pulls the o-ring out of place, so perhaps gentler handling is in order.     <li> I began using a Waterpik in the mid 1980s upon the advice of my orthodontist.  That unit came with one basic, classic pik which worked fine.  The pressure setting on that machine was plenty strong enough if set at three or four.  Much more than that was too high pressure for me.  That old unit had a compact design with a slim profile, too, so it took up less space than this \\&quot;Ultra Water Flosser,\\&quot; and it possessed a modicum of simple elegance.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;After twenty plus years, my old Waterpik finally died.  I read rave reviews about this model on Amazon.  Amazon reviewers can usually be trusted to tell the good, the bad, and the ugly.  The good reviews of this model were plentiful, so I bought it.  I used it for the first time today, and I must say I am extremely disappointed in it.  Below are the pros and cons from my viewpoint.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Pro:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(1)  With the pressure setting set to ten, this unit is better than nothing but not much.  It will help flush out larger food particles from between the teeth.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Con:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(1)  This unit is far too large and takes up far more than its fair share of space on the vanity and even in the&lt;br /&gt;cupboard below.  It&#x27;s large, bulky design has absolutely no sense of elegance to it.  Steve Jobs and Apple brought the concept of sleek elegant design (some even say sexy) to computers and other electronics and made a fortune.  Waterpik seems to be going in the exact OPPOSITE direction.  Big, bulky, and ugly are the only words to describe this unit.  It is a space hog with no visual appeal whatsoever.  It reminds me of what those old office adding machines look like in comparison to a hand held calculator that uses a microchip.  The old adding machines were big, bulky, and took up a lot of room on a desk top, but the new calculators took up the merest corner of the desk top and slipped easily into a lap drawer whence not in use.  Whilst everyone else has been pursuing smaller size and a more elegant profile over the last forty years or more, Waterpik seems to be opting for ungainly bulkiness.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(2)  The plastic feels positively flimsy compared to my old Waterpik.  Waterpik customer service told me this is because the plastic in this unit is more readily biodegradable than the old type of plastic.  The woman said new laws prevent them from using the old type of plastic.  I am in favour of anything that helps the environment, but this still feels as though this plastic will not hold up for very many years.  The box says Made In China, and everything about this unit definitely shouts VERY CHEAPLY MADE IN CHINA.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(3)  The extra specialised tips do not seem to be of any real value.  They are nothing more than bells and whistles that the manufacturer uses to justify charging more money for the product.  The classic tip is all anyone needs, and I vouchsafe this statement based on the fact that I wore braces for five years.  All I ever used for more than twenty years was the basic, classic tip, and I have always had excellent dental check-ups even during the five years I wore braces.  Moreover, although I am a very experienced Waterpik user, I flooded my vanity trying these specialised tips.  To use these specialised tips, one has to look into the mirror to see what one is doing.  Looking into the mirror means raising one&#x27;s head to mirror height.  Raising one&#x27;s head to mirror height whilst using these specialised tips causes water to go absolutely everywhere.  I did not have this problem even the first time I used the old model with just the basic, classic tip.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(4)  The water pressure on this unit is NOT the same as the old model I used for twenty years.  As another reviewer commented, and I heartily agree, the old model had plenty of pressure set at three or four.  This model has to be turned up to ten to approach the pressure of the old model set at three or four.  Even set at ten, it does not feel strong enough to me, and it certainly is not equal tomy old Waterpik&#x27;s pressure set at ten.  Waterpik customer service told me that they had a bad batch of these a few years ago where the motors were not strong enough.  She suggested that I had gotten one of those models.  I had her check the serial number and the model number of my unit.  It was manufactured in 2013, so it is not one from their bad batch a few years ago.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(5)  On the lower settings, this model does not \\&quot;pick\\&quot; between the teeth so much as it simply floods them with a very weak stream of water.  Taking a mouthful of water and swishing it around in one&#x27;s mouth creates more pressure than this unit creates on the lower settings.  Waterpik customer service said this model has a different type of motor than the old ones had and uses less electricity.  Really?  Well, speaking for myself, I would rather pay a few extra dollars a year on electricity and have the old motor.  By way of analogy, there are \\&quot;low flush commodes\\&quot; and \\&quot;low flow shower heads\\&quot; on the market, too, and I have used them before, but I certainly would never INTENTIONALLY install one in my bathroom.  Why?  Because the pressure is too insubstantial.  I want to feel a strong shower if I am going to shower, and I want to feel a strong pressure from my Waterpik if I am going to water floss my teeth.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;In conclusion, after twenty plus years as a user of a Waterpik, I am deeply disappointed in this unit.  Large, bulky and totally aesthetically unappealing; plastic that feels cheap and insubstantial; a motor that feels underpowered; assorted specialised tips that really do nothing more or better than the basic, classic tip; and Waterpik&#x27;s customer service&#x27;s attitude of \\&quot;you are WRONG this is just as good if not better than the old model,\\&quot; all lead me to give this unit a BIG thumbs down.  As for Waterpik&#x27;s customer service representative, please know that the customer is never WRONG.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I do not believe this unit will give you any better oral health than using an electrictoothbrush, floss, and a manual tongue scraper followed by a good mouthwash.  If anyone is interested in buying mine at a substantial discount, please feel free to contact me: one_old_reader@yahoo.com</li>

Alcohol also \\&quot;dries\\&quot; and \\&quot;Dry Mouth\\&quot; is something that needs attention and possible treatment.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&gt; Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (SLS) is an ingredient in many personal care products, including soap, shampoo, toothpaste, and mouthwash. It is relatively inexpensive and foams up easily.  It is often described as a detergent or degreaser, but it functions primarily as a surfactant, so that oil-based ingredients can combine more easily with water-based ingredients. A secondary function of SLS is to provide the foaming action that makes it feel like something spectacular is happening in your mouth. There is little scientific proof that SLS removes tartar, plaque, or biofilm.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&gt; You will likely benefit from seriously considering not using SLS containing products in your mouth. SLS has been blamed for a number of different conditions, including canker sores and bad breath.
